channel.title: Comments on: Jasmine.Async: Making Asynchronous Testing With Jasmine Suck Less

item.title: By: Alon Salant
item.dc:creator: Alon Salant
item.description: Oops. I see that another poster already pointed this out.
item.content:encoded: Oops. I see that another poster already pointed this out.

item.title: By: Alon Salant
item.dc:creator: Alon Salant
item.description:
It's worth noting that jasmine-node has supported the same async style as Mocha since Feb 2012. http://bytes.goodeggs.com/post/13332056735/better-asynchronous-jasmine-node-specs
Note to the author of Jasmine.Async - if you wanted you could have Jasmine.Async patch jasmine (as shown in the post above) so then when you include it, jasmine would support the done callback without having to create a new AsyncSpec.
item.content:encoded:
It’s worth noting that jasmine-node has supported the same async style as Mocha since Feb 2012. http://bytes.goodeggs.com/post/13332056735/better-asynchronous-jasmine-node-specs

Note to the author of Jasmine.Async – if you wanted you could have Jasmine.Async patch jasmine (as shown in the post above) so then when you include it, jasmine would support the done callback without having to create a new AsyncSpec.

item.title: By: millermedeiros
item.dc:creator: millermedeiros
item.description: jasmine-node monkey patches the `it`, `beforeEach` and `afterEach` methods: https://github.com/mhevery/jasmine-node/blob/master/lib/jasmine-node/async-callback.js - I find it simpler.
item.content:encoded: jasmine-node monkey patches the `it`, `beforeEach` and `afterEach` methods: https://github.com/mhevery/jasmine-node/blob/master/lib/jasmine-node/async-callback.js – I find it simpler.

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description: the it statement doesn't need to be async in this case, though the plugin does support it.
item.content:encoded: the it statement doesn’t need to be async in this case, though the plugin does support it.

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description: the it statement doesn't need to be async in this case, though the plugin does support it.
item.content:encoded: the it statement doesn’t need to be async in this case, though the plugin does support it.

item.title: By: Dan Hollenbeck
item.dc:creator: Dan Hollenbeck
item.content:encoded:
Typo in your gist?

async.it(“did stuff”, function(){
instead of

it(“did stuff”, function(){

item.content:encoded:
Typo in your gist?

async.it(“did stuff”, function(){
instead of

item.description:
I won't repeat myself on this issue once more. Please see my opinions here:
https://github.com/busterjs/buster/issues/193
item.content:encoded:

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description: if you can, do that. it's not always possible, though. There are times when it's far more difficult or creates too much of a brittle test, to spy/mock/stub the internal working of an object. in those cases, async tests are important. the prime example for me, right now, is WinJS/Promises. but also in API design for my Backbone applications, I often want to ensure my promises are working correctly for loading data through an API in my app instead of directly through a model or collection.
item.content:encoded: if you can, do that. it’s not always possible, though. There are times when it’s far more difficult or creates too much of a brittle test, to spy/mock/stub the internal working of an object. in those cases, async tests are important. the prime example for me, right now, is WinJS/Promises. but also in API design for my Backbone applications, I often want to ensure my promises are working correctly for loading data through an API in my app instead of directly through a model or collection.

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description: in what way is this limiting? there's nothing you can do with runs/waitsFor that can't be done with a simple "done()" call.
item.content:encoded: in what way is this limiting? there’s nothing you can do with runs/waitsFor that can’t be done with a simple “done()” call.
